It did finally, thank god. Worst prolonged pain I've had. Took almost 3 months to go away... But that's probably because I tried to push through it and continue working on a project that required lots of staring at the computer.

Obviously we don't know even a fraction of what is going on, but I think the two keys I can say for me were inflammation and "convergence insufficiency". Antiinflammatories treatments helped- cbd, steroid drops, antihistamines too for whatever reason.

All the basic tips to increase moisture are good too- humidity, wear glasses, avoid air flow at your face, yada yada.

But I'm now beginning to think the convergence insufficiency was a big part of the problem. In part because ultimately the only way I got better was to vastly cut back screen time and basically rest my body and eyes lying in the dark for like 2 weeks. Several days of total bedrest and no screens.

But while resting and avoiding screens helps, staying indoors and being a shut in is, ironically, part of the whole problem. There are papers on how CI doubled during early days of lockdown and the actual rates are probably much higher. And it's not just screen time, it's more just being in confined spaces where your visual focus is always extremely near.

So while you may need to avoid sunlight if your eyes are acutely hurting, eventually part of the treatment is probably to get back out into the outside world where you will focus on things more than 10 feet away.

Also, any ADHD meds or other stimulants can make this effect worse. I had to cut back on using Adderall because daily use will start to bring back the eye pain and headaches. I imagine dextroamphetamine is preferably to the adderall formulations that have levo-amphetamine, but that's a bit out there.

And of course, it's possible none of these things are the source of your issue. I looked at everything from MS to parasites to eye herpes. And while I do think there was a big neuro-inflammatory/viral component given it started right after getting COVID, the entire ecosystem is so complex that there's no point trying to parse it .

Basically my mistake was to listen to doctors who said "normal eye strain wouldn't cause you this much pain". Maybe that's true, but it was really the simple/healthy/holistic stuff- rest, "fresh air", NSAIDs,ice packs, humidity, etc. That helped way more than any of the tests the doctors tried.

Though I'll probably stay on Xidraa for a few months to give my eyes some extra protection while they continue to heal.
